text:
- So one of the reasons why I
really wanted to start at AWS

is because I wanted to be
challenged and I wanted to work

with the most brilliant
people in the world.
And I came in with that expectation,
and my expectations were only exceeded.

- Each team and each business
unit within Amazon operates

with its own autonomy and has
the ability to make decisions.

- And within one week, I
was spinning up meetings
to structure a global security roadshow,
and it was very successful,
because everyone was so willing to give
of their time and expertise,
and that kind of experience for me

really set the stage with
the kind of collaboration
that you experience here at AWS.

- You are instantly
given so much autonomy,
no matter what level that you come in at.

If you have a big idea, no
one's going to stop you.
It's really just a matter of finding
the way to make it happen.

- Part of AWS culture is
that builder mentality.

So go in, and getting
hands-on with AWS solutions,

building new architectures,
and solving problems.

- Sitting in the audience at
re:Invent a few years ago,
and seeing customer win success stories,
and remembering to myself,

"Hey, I was part of some
of those solutions,"

and there's a lot of pride
that I have working on,
you know, big solutions for customers.

- This is the kind of place
where you can really thrive
if you want to bring your big ideas,
dig in, and learn something new,

really deeply try to
understand our customers,
and solve for them in new ways.
- Now, when I'm doing interviews,

candidates are asking
me this all the time,
like, "Why did you join AWS?"
And the answer is always the same,
because I believe this place,
more than any other place on earth,

again, because of the culture,
because of the people,

has the ability to completely
change the landscape,
and impact the world.
(light music)
